title-group.article-title: A performance-based method for calculating the design thickness of compacted clay liners exposed to high strength leachate under simulated landfill conditions

contrib-group.aff: Department of Environmental Engineering, Graduate Faculty of Environment, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mahdi Jalili Ghazizade, Department of Environmental Engineering, Graduate Faculty of Environment, No. 23, Ghods St., Enghelab Ave., Tehran, Iran Email: mjalili@ut.ac.ir

abstract.p: Compacted clay liners (CCLs) when feasible, are preferred to composite geosynthetic liners. The thickness of CCLs is typically prescribed by each country’s environmental protection regulations. However, considering the fact that construction of CCLs represents a significant portion of overall landfill construction costs; a performance based design of liner thickness would be preferable to ‘one size fits all’ prescriptive standards. In this study researchers analyzed the hydraulic behaviour of a compacted clayey soil in three laboratory pilot scale columns exposed to high strength leachate under simulated landfill conditions. The temperature of the simulated CCL at the surface was maintained at 40 ± 2 °C and a vertical pressure of 250 kPa was applied to the soil through a gravel layer on top of the 50 cm thick CCL where high strength fresh leachate was circulated at heads of 15 and 30 cm simulating the flow over the CCL. Inverse modelling using HYDRUS-1D indicated that the hydraulic conductivity after 180 days was decreased about three orders of magnitude in comparison with the values measured prior to the experiment. A number of scenarios of different leachate heads and persistence time were considered and saturation depth of the CCL was predicted through modelling. Under a typical leachate head of 30 cm, the saturation depth was predicted to be less than 60 cm for a persistence time of 3 years. This approach can be generalized to estimate an effective thickness of a CCL instead of using prescribed values, which may be conservatively overdesigned and thus unduly costly.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Among various waste treatment and disposal options, sanitary landfills are employed as the primary method for waste disposal in most countries. About 40 to 80% and 60 to 90% of municipal solid waste (MSW) were disposed of in landfills in developed and developing countries, respectively in recent years (EEA, 2009; Khajuria et al., 2010). Although much has changed in this regard in many European countries, it appears that sanitary landfills still receive about half of the MSW stream in North America. In developing countries, however, landfilling of MSW in a not necessarily sanitary manner is practically the sole method of disposal. Landfills are anticipated to continue serving as a major waste disposal option for foreseeable future as they are comparably less costly, simple to construct and operate and able to accommodate a wide range of wastes and fluctuating waste volumes compared to other waste handling options (Gupta et al., 2007; Hu and Chen, 2001).

Leachate generation and the associated potential contamination threat to local soil and groundwater can be considered one of the critical potential negative impacts of landfilling (Kjeldsen et al., 2002). Different types of bottom liners can be used to impede if not wholly prevent migration of leachate from deposited wastes to underlying groundwater, particularly if the accumulated leachate is removed and treated before discharge. Construction of liners in a sanitary landfill comprises a major portion of overall costs. Cost of compacted soil liners vary with thickness and the distance from sources of clayey soils. The approximate cost of constructing a 60 cm thick compacted clay liner (CCL) is estimated to be about US$25 000 per hectare assuming clay is available onsite, to about US$160 000 per hectare if clay needs to be transported from a distance of 100 km. Higher costs are estimated for thicker clay liners, for instance a 90 cm thick CCL constructed with onsite material could cost about US$36 000 per hectare. Thus, an optimal site-specific design of a landfill lining system can significantly contribute to lowering the total landfill construction costs.

When feasible, compacted clayey liner can be considered as a technically efficient liner practically preventing leachate migration to subsurface layers even if no geomembrane liner is present (Rowe et al., 2004). Some of the advantages of CCL over geosynthetics are higher durability, potential for adsorbing some contaminants, capable of tolerating higher overburden pressure and lower costs when available at a relatively close distance (Kalkan, 2009; Sivrikaya, 2008). These advantages have led to widespread use of CCL in arid and semi-arid regions (Bouazza and Bowders, 2010) where clay is abundant (Obrike et al., 2009) and groundwater level is relatively deep. As an instance, use of geomembranes in landfill lining system is not recommended in Kuwait due to critical alterations experienced in geomembrane properties including but not limited to tensile strength and tear resistance as a result of harsh climatic conditions (Al-Yaqout and Townsend, 2001).

Assuming a certain hydraulic conductivity for a CCL, a theoretical optimal liner thickness can be calculated that will minimize the volume of leachate than will pass through a liner (Bagchi, 2004). Thickness of CCL can be determined through either a product-based or a performance-based approach (Katsumi et al., 2001). Current standards for CCL thickness are typically product-based prescribing certain specifications for the CCL including but not limited to hydraulic conductivity and thickness. In many cases the prescribed specifications could be strictly above the actually required values resulting in higher cost. This is particularly true for the developing countries with no standards on CCL specifications as they would tend to employ standards developed in other countries. These standards significantly vary in different countries as shown in Table 1. In addition to the method employed in CCL thickness design, it should be noted that CCL liner effectiveness is significantly influenced by the moisture content of the clay, the skill of the construction crew, and the effectiveness of the QA/QC team during CCL installation.

caption.p: Required specifications of CCL in different countries.

sec.p: The required thickness of CCL ranges from 60 to 100 cm and 50 to 200 cm with and without incorporating a geomembrane, respectively. Thus a performance-based approach has found more preference in recent years (Foose et al., 1996; Giroud et al., 1998; Rowe, 1998). When using the performance-based design of CCL, leachate head and its persistence on top of the liner are the key factors to be considered. Leachate head can be determined using different methods such as Moore’s method (Cooke and Rowe, 2008) as well as methods developed by Giroud et al. (1992) and McEnroe (1993). The method developed by McEnroe (1993) has a higher accuracy and is therefore recommended for design of leachate drainage systems (Qian et al., 2004). Leachate collection systems are typically designed for a maximum leachate head of 30 cm while cases of 30 to 58 cm have been reported (Bagchi, 2004). In arid and semi-arid regions in which atmospheric precipitation is scarce, different magnitudes of leachate heads can be expected. Another issue to be addressed when designing a clayey barrier system is the duration that leachate head is maintained on top of the liner. This in turn corresponds to the waste disposal capacity of landfill. In other words, waste disposal capacity of landfill can influence the persistence of the leachate head over the liner and consequently liner thickness and associated costs.

Concentration of organic content of leachate can also considerably influence the hydraulic behaviour of CCLs. Even in arid and semi-arid regions a substantial amount of leachate can be produced resulting mainly from the moisture content of the organic fraction of the waste (Safari and Baronian, 2002; Safari and Nabi Bidhendi, 2007; Safari et al., 2011). Several leachate-CCL compatibility studies seem to have yielded different results (Arasan, 2010). In some cases the organic content of the leachate has led to a reduction in the diffuse double layer and therefore an increased hydraulic conductivity (Kaya and Durukan, 2004; Schmitz, 2006). However in some cases the re-precipitation of dissolved solids in leachate has been shown to chemically clog the pores within the CCL and reduce the hydraulic conductivity (VanGulck and Rowe, 2004). Biological clogging through formation of biofilm around clay particles has also been reported to result in a reduction of hydraulic conductivity (Cooke et al., 2001; Francisca and Glatstein, 2010). It was shown by Safari (2006) that in the longer term the hydraulic conductivity of CCL was significantly reduced mainly through biological clogging.

The objective of this study was to devise a methodology for preparing a performance-based design of CCL thickness which will probably result in a more efficient use of materials and installation labour that together can reduce the costs associated with liner placement. Accordingly, a pilot scale column experiment was conducted in which compacted clayey soil was exposed to high strength leachate obtained fresh from an operating landfill. Landfill conditions were physically simulated in three columns in terms of expected temperature on the surface of the liner along with vertical pressure on top of the liner. Different leachate heads were selected and profile of moisture content in the columns was monitored. Hydraulic behaviour of the columns was determined through a one-dimensional inverse modelling based on which predictive scenarios were defined and simulated aimed at finding relationships between thickness of CCL, leachate head over CCL and the duration it persists.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: Three pilot scale columns were designed to simulate boundary conditions typically experienced over landfill barrier systems. The columns were made of 10 mm thick steel pipes with a diameter of 60 cm and length of 100 cm. In order to simulate the flow of leachate over the CCL, inflow and outflow valves were installed through which heated leachate stored in an elevated tank flowed into the column and on top of the CCL at a specified head and was discharged from the other side through outflow head adjustment valves into a pumping chamber circulating the leachate into the storage tank. Outflow valves were installed in a way that 15 and 30 cm leachate heads could be formed on top of the CCL. A 4 cm gravel layer typically used in leachate drainage systems was placed over the compacted clayey soil within the column. Figure 1 shows a schematic cross-section of the column along with a picture indicating the experiment configuration.

caption.p: Configuration of experimental setup (a) layout of the overall experimental setup and (b) schematic cross section of the columns.

sec.p: As indicated in Figure 1, a 15 cm layer of sand was placed at the bottom of the columns and was compacted to provide a free drainage bottom boundary condition. The 50 cm clayey soil was compacted in five layers of 10 cm thick at 90% of maximum density in accordance with modified Proctor method (US EPA, 1995). Moisture content was increased to optimum moisture content plus 2%. A 30 cm thick layer of gravel was then placed on the compacted clayey soil as the leachate drainage layer.

Moisture content and temperature were monitored at certain locations within the compacted clayey soil as shown in Figure 1. Moisture content was monitored using 14-22-05 gypsum blocks supplied by Eijkelkamp positioned at depths of 10, 25 and 40 cm of the 50 cm deep compacted clayey soil within the column and connected to a data logger.

sec.title: Clayey soil
sec.p: The properties of the clayey soil compacted in the columns are presented in Table 2. This soil was obtained from an area adjacent to Kahrizak landfill in southern Tehran, Iran.

sec.title: Temperature and vertical pressure
sec.p: Different fractions of organic matter can be found in municipal solid waste in different countries ranging from 20% to more than 70% by weight (Barone et al., 2000). In Iran, the waste typically contains about 70% food waste (Safari and Nabi Bidhendi, 2007). Biological degradation of this part of waste increases the temperature within the landfill (Rowe and Arnepalli, 2008). This increase in temperature forms a temperature gradient which can lead to alteration of hydraulic performance of the liner (Southern and Rowe, 2005). Recent studies indicated that in normal operation of conventional landfills, biodegradation of the organic fraction in municipal solid waste can result in an increase in the temperature of the bottom of the landfill to about 30 to 45 °C (Koerner and Koerner, 2006; Rowe, 2005).

In order to simulate temperature in this study, a temperature of 40 ± 2 °C was maintained at the surface of the compacted clayey soil within the columns. This was done through heating the leachate within the elevated tank using an electric heater. A feedback Pt100 thermocouple was installed on the surface of the compacted clayey soil within the column aimed at adjusting the heater. Four additional thermocouples were also installed at depths of 10, 20, 35 and 50 cm of the compacted soil and were connected to a digital thermometer.

In addition to temperature, simulation of vertical pressure was also found to be essential as it presumably could result in decreasing effective porosity of the soil and consequently reducing its hydraulic conductivity (Foged and Baumann, 1999). Therefore a vertical pressure of about 250 kPa was applied to the column equal to vertical load of 30 m of waste disposed of at a typical average density of 800 kg m−3 (Bagchi, 2004). Similar pressure has also been used in other studies dealing with liner performance simulating about 18 m of waste at a density of 1300 kg m−3 (Gudina and Brachman, 2006). The pressure was mechanically applied using six screws that pressed a 10mm thick steel plate positioned on top of the gravel layer. The pressure was measured using a torque wrench (BRIOL TOOL TS300). Furthermore, the friction between the soil and the inner side of the column wall was minimized using a friction treatment method described by Brachman et al. (2008).

sec.title: Leachate
sec.p: Real leachate was used in this study to simulate landfill conditions. Fresh leachate, as characterized in Table 3, was obtained from Kahrizak landfill in southern Tehran, Iran where the precipitation rate is 250 mm year−1. The municipal solid waste generated in Tehran is currently disposed of at this landfill at a rate of 7000 tones day−1. The incoming MSW to this site is characterized through its high organic content which is directly associated with the high portion of putrescible waste (i.e. about 69%). Other components such as plastics, paper and cardboard and textiles are generated at the rate of 9.7, 8.1 and 3.4%, respectively.

caption.p: Characteristics of the fresh leachate obtained from Kahrizak landfill.

sec.p: Three fresh leachate samples used as throughout the experiment were collected at a 2 month interval from a newly filled waste trench. To maintain sample quality, samples were transferred to laboratory in 20 L plastic containers at standard conditions and were immediately analyzed in triplicates.

The low pH and high concentrations of BOD5 and COD as shown in Table 3 are indicators of leachate freshness. Although organic loading of leachate is presumed to decrease over time as the landfill ages, fresh leachate was consistently applied to the columns throughout the study.

sec.title: Mathematical model
sec.p: Hydraulic conductivity of the compacted soil was measured in the laboratory prior to the experiment (i.e. 1.2 E−7 m s−1). However, the authors hypothesized that the hydraulic conductivity of the soil within the columns can change over time as the soil is continuously exposed to high strength leachate. In order to estimate the hydraulic parameters of the columns mathematical simulation of the flow (moisture content of the soil) was found necessary. Given the dimensions of the columns a one dimensional modelling approach was considered to be the case and HYDRUS-1D was used. This model was used in studies of similar nature (Siyal and Skaggs, 2009).

The mixed form of Richards equation (Equation (1)) is solved by the model using a Galerkin finite element method (Celia et al., 1990; Simunek et al., 2009), in which h is the water pressure head (L), θis the volumetric water content (L3 L−3), t is time (T), x is the spatial coordinate (L) (positive upward), S is the sink term (L3L−3T−1), α is the angle between the flow direction and the vertical axis, and K is the unsaturated hydraulic conductivity function (L T−1) given by Equation (2). Unsaturated hydraulic conductivity of the soil in terms of soil water retention parameters is determined using the van Genuchten equation (Equations (3) and (4)).

where θr and θS are the residual and saturated water contents (L3 L−3), respectively; Ks is the saturated hydraulic conductivity (L T−1); α is an empirical constant that is the inverse of the air-entry value (or bubbling pressure) (L−1); n is a pore-size distribution index (unit-less); l is an empirical shape parameter; m = l-l/n (unit-less); and Se is the effective saturation given by Equation (5):

HYDRUS-1D also includes an inverse modelling module through which hydraulic parameters can be estimated based on observations. The modelling scheme in this study comprised two stages. In the first stage, an inverse model was constructed to estimate the hydraulic parameters of the compacted clayey soil using the observed moisture content values along the soil profile. Using the estimated hydraulic parameters, in the second stage, different combinations of leachate head and persistence duration were defined as possible scenarios aimed at predicting the saturation depth as a function of time and leachate head. Thus the depth at which moisture content would reach saturation state and therefore readily available to flow out of the liner was determined for a given leachate head and duration throughout which the head is present. Accordingly the saturation depth plus a fraction of depth to cover for uncertainties can be considered as the required CCL thickness.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Moisture content within the soil profile was measured every two to three days for 180 days. The experiment is being continued in order to evaluate longer term hydraulic behaviour of the CCL; however, only the results obtained after 180 days are presented in this paper. Taking into account the observations of moisture content at different depths of the compacted soil, an inverse modelling was performed using HYDRUS-1D in order to estimate the hydraulic parameters of the soil. Initial conditions were set as the moisture content during compaction (i.e. 20% by volume). Upper and lower boundary conditions were set to be constant pressure head and free drainage, respectively. The results of inverse modelling are shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Results of inverse modelling of the compacted soil using HYDRUS-1D: (a) Pilot 1, 30 cm head; (b) Pilot 2, 30 cm head; (c) Pilot 3, 15 cm head. D, sensor position; Obs, observed data; model, inverse modelling result.

sec.p: In Pilot 1, moisture content started to increase at the depth of 10 cm after 20 days and reached saturation state at this depth after 60 days. After 130 days the moisture content appears to increase at 25 cm of the depth. This depth remains unsaturated until 180 days after starting the experiment. After 180 days, no moisture increase was observed at the depth of 40 cm where the moisture content maintained its initial value. Similar situations were observed in Pilot 2 and 3. The results of parameter estimation through inverse modelling are summarized in Table 4.

caption.p: Hydraulic parameters of compacted clayey soil as estimated through inverse modelling by HYDRUS-1D.

sec.p: According to the results of inverse modelling, it appears that the hydraulic conductivity of the compacted soil within the column has decreased about three orders of magnitude in comparison with the measure hydraulic conductivity prior to experiment. Factors presumably leading to this lowered hydraulic conductivity include application of vertical pressure at 250 kPa, possibility of chemical precipitation occurring on the surface of the compacted soil and biological growth leading to partial clogging of the surface of the soil as reported earlier by Safari (2006) in column tests conducted with similar high strength leachate.

Hydraulic conductivity of the compacted soil where a leachate head of 15 cm was applied was calculated by the model to be about 10% less than the columns with 30 cm leachate head. Other parameters seem to have not been influenced by the leachate head.

sec.title: Design scenarios and estimation of saturation depth
sec.p: Various leachate head scenarios can be taken into consideration when trying to find the saturation depth of a CCL. In this study, leachate generation in an arid or semi-arid region was considered to be the case. It was shown by Safari and Baronian (2002) that the main source of leachate was the moisture content of the considerably high organic fraction of the waste. It can therefore be assumed that the duration through which a range of leachate heads exists on the liner corresponds to the size of the cell or trench where the waste is disposed of. In other words, leachate generation is not expected to continue long after the trench is filled even with no final cap installed. Scarcity of precipitation supports this hypothesis. The larger the trench size, the longer the duration of leachate head presence on the liner. However, smaller trenches can lead to an increase in dead spaces and therefore adversely influence disposal efficiency. On the other hand, large trenches can result in longer durations of leachate formation and persistence on the liner. Determination of a combination of leachate head and presence duration on the liner is beyond the scope of this study; however, some realistic scenarios were considered in this study and were analysed through modelling. These scenarios cover a range of possible leachate heads and persistence duration for trenches with 6 to 48 month capacity. Conservatively it was also assumed that the leachate head will persist for 6 months after closing the trench .

Leachate drainage systems are typically designed with the objective of preventing the leachate head from exceeding 30 cm at the peak of the leachate generation rate. Assuming there would be no biological clogging of the leachate drainage layer, lower leachate heads can be expected on the liner throughout the life of a given trench. However, despite the care taken in design of leachate drainage layers, biological clogging is inevitable in many cases. This means that the leachate can only partially flow downwards and accumulate on the liner. In other words the leachate drainage layer itself acts as part of the lining system in which case the head on the liner can be presumed to be lower than the design value. In any case several heads ranging from 10 up to 50 cm were analysed in this study to cover a realistically possible spectrum of leachate heads. These scenarios were modelled using the hydraulic parameters estimated through inverse modelling and the results are summarized in Table 5. In the forward modelling of the scenarios, the hydraulic parameters of Pilot 1 were selected as the worst case (i.e. highest hydraulic conductivity in comparison with the other two pilots). The results are also graphically depicted in Figure 3 in the form of saturation depth as a function of leachate head persistence duration for specific leachate head values. A logarithmic relationship between the saturation depth and leachate persistence duration was found to fit well to the modelling results. The logarithmic functions resulting from regression are presented in Table 6.

caption.p: Saturation depth of compacted clayey soil in various leachate head – persistence duration scenarios (in cm).
Logarithmic relationship between the saturation depth of compacted clayey soil and leachate persistence duration for a range of leachate heads.
Results of logarithmic regression of saturation depth of the compacted clayey soil as a function of leachate persistence duration for a range of leachate heads.

sec.p: These relationships can be used for a range of design conditions. As an example in an extreme case of a trench in an arid region, if a 50 cm leachate head is assumed to have existed on the liner for 5 years, the saturation depth for this specific compacted clayey soil would be about 90 cm. In a moderate case, assuming a leachate head of 30 cm being present on the liner for 3 years (i.e. a trench capacity of more than 2 years), the saturation depth would be less than 60 cm. Based on these results the appropriate thickness of the CCL (if a similar soil is used) can be estimated through incorporating the safety factors originating from model uncertainties and errors.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A clayey soil typically used in CCL construction within MSW landfills in a semi-arid region was studied in terms of its hydraulic performance when exposed to real leachate under simulated landfill conditions. The results of inverse modelling indicated that the hydraulic conductivity of the soil was about three orders of magnitude lower than what was measured prior to the experiment. A performance-based approach was employed aimed at determining the saturation depth of the compacted soil at various realistically possible leachate head and persistence duration scenarios. The results indicated that using this approach and the methodology presented in this paper can provide the designers with a realistic optimum design of CCLs in terms of required thickness to prevent downward migration of leachate. Although the results presented in this paper are obtained through testing a specific clayey soil, the methodology can be generalized as a design process replacing prescribed hydraulic conductivity and thickness for CCL.

It should be noted that the design thickness cannot solely be determined based on hydraulic behaviour; the diffusive behaviour of the liner along with possible biological growth on the surface and near surface regions of the liner should also be considered. This study is the first part of a three-stage study (i.e. diffusive and biological behaviour of compacted soil liners are the other two subsequent stages of the study). A study on the diffusion of contaminants in the liner following a similar approach to that presented in this paper is to be conducted as a continuation to the present study. A qualitative analysis of possible biological growth (if any) on the surface of the liner in the experiments presented in this paper will also be done after disassembling the experimental setup and the results will be presented in another paper. Further research is required to determine the hydraulic behaviour of leachate within landfills to more definitively specify the maximum safe leachate heads and their temporal variation.
